You said earlier that mindfulness always comes before concentration, but based on what you just defined, I would think it would be the opposite.

MN 20: The Removal of Distracting Thoughts

If a hindrance comes up, one thing to do is to acknowledge it and observe it, but on the other hand, one can bring up its opposite. Do you do either depending on what is needed? Sometimes when I bring up the opposite, it prevents me from seeing it.
Do you have any advice for obsessive thoughts, thinking the same thing again and again?

Does jhāna arise only in seated meditation?

Is jhāna only in meditation?
Only farangs [Westerners] go into meditation rock climbing! Does he contemplate the Four Noble Truths?|Ajahn Chah
If there isn't an intention, [meditation] isn't useful for the goal?
The story that we hear frequently about the Buddha as a child in the cattle pasture with his father. He talks about going into a pleasant, rapturous state.  Would you consider that jhāna?
MN 36.31 Mahāsaccaka Sutta
Absorption dependent on the pleasure that comes from sense contact may not be completely wholesome.
Isn't rapture and joy a sensual pleasure?
You can actually give yourself permission to enjoy the meditation.

So it [jhāna] is still a conditional thing?
The rapture and joy that are being described are not pleasure, right?
Path of Purification p. 139
Does jhāna exclusively contain the five mental states?
MN 111 Anupada Sutta

What's the difference between directed thought and mindfulness?

So the rapture and joy has dropped away between second and third jhāna?

What is the difference between ekaggatā and vitakka?

This reminds me of finding a unified theory of the universe.

So the one who knows includes the other five sense bases?
